title: God is evil for creating people he knows are destined for hell

author: Anselmian
text: Sure, God creates the damned knowing that they will go to Hell, but this doesn't contradict love. It means that even the pains of Hell, as bad as they are, and as much as God doesn't want them for their own sake, are to God worth it for the existence of the person who is damned. God's love (which is, fundamentally, his will that we exist, and accomplish to the degree we can the intrinsic ends of that existence) rightly embraces not only the morally and spiritually successful, but the unsuccessful as well.

author: Anselmian
text:
If I love my child, and want him to accomplish his interests to the degree that he can, then of course I have to will him to exist, even allowing for the evils he will bring about or suffer, though I also abhor those evils precisely because they take away from his existence. It is precisely because my child does not exist yet, and I have not chosen to love him yet, that it is thinkable (and perhaps advisable, since I am not required to love him yet) not to have the child. You might object, if I have the child, that I was not loving toward his victims, but it would not be possible to say that I was not loving toward the child.

Likewise, the founder of a city or a nation, if he is at all versed in the histories of cities or nations, can foresee with certainty all the evil which would be brought about by this founding. We wouldn't say that the founder is unloving toward that city merely because he foresaw the evils that would have resulted and decided that the inherent costs were worth it anyway.

In short, it makes perfect sense.

author: Anselmian
text:
>This certainly wasn't his goal but of course you got to twist things to say that he is achieving his goals. He is not. He is failing and suffering greatly, what was the point of it?

As incredibly serious as the failure of rape and sufferings of imprisonment are, they are not complete privations of being-human. He would, for instance, still be the recipient of my love, still be made in the image of God. There are some goods which just can't be removed from us as long as we exist. We aren't reducible to the transient, subjective goals we conceive from time to time. Rather, we are constituted by the essential goals of the human agent as such: to know and love God and through him each other, and to be known by and beloved by others. As much has my son has lost, and as limited as his existence will be in prison, he hasn't actually lost everything.

If I genuinely love my child, I could not logically say that I wish he had never existed, no matter how badly things turn out. If I love someone, I abhor what takes away from them because I affirm their existence. The total privation of non-existence can never be preferable (even if, under abnormal conditions, it may seem so to the sufferer) to even a very meagre existence.  One who exists necessarily accomplishes more of the ends of human existence (even if it might be comparatively few next to a more successful person) than one who does not.

>If the child got to live for an infinity and behind bars would you still do it? I am curious to see how inhumane you could get to defend your beliefs, thus far you are already quite inhumane in what you want to do.

Firstly, Hell is, though not non-existence, certainly a form of death in Christianity, not everlasting life. It is permanent precisely because the capacity to exist in any other state has been lost: there is no multiplicity of future states that the damned could achieve, that are meaningfully continuous with the life he has led. That humans can lose their vitality and mobility is a perfectly ordinary fact about human existence. For the damned, just as for us who approach death without hope, the chief part of life, for the sake of which our existence was made, has become something lying mainly (but not completely) in the past.

On even the severest doctrine of Hell, however, even the worst human existence does not come to *nothing* in the end, even if it comes to very little. As little as the damned may have served God, his fellow-man, or himself, God at least does not relinquish his love of the damned. The pains and privations of Hell manifest the true condition of a soul, once the temporary life he has enjoyed runs its allotted course, but as long as he exists, such a soul manifests *some* good. The pains and privations of Hell, as bad as they are, are permitted for the sake of the existence of the damned themselves.

To bring it back to more familiar reality, the whole underpinning of my position is that since we avoid privation because it takes away from our fulfilment, and because we achieve that fulfilment to some degree as long as we exist, it is never preferrable to one who wills fulfilment for us to will that we had never been. This reminds us of what is fundamentally at stake in our relations with each other- if the chief object of concern is our fellow human beings, we are not merely trying to minimise suffering, but to affirm being, and between the two the latter has to come first, on pain of incoherence.

author: Anselmian
text:
Any sound definition of love has to will the good for the object of that love, and the good is in turn rooted in what it is for them to exist. It's impossible even for us to look out for anyone's genuine interests apart from willing their existence and its ends. It also explains why love in us is an echo of the most-fundamental reality who, through willing his creations to be, loves all reality into being. No one is forced to listen, of course, but they'll benefit if they doâ€” whether they realise it or not, they are already loving in this way, even if unconsciously. Refining the concept of love in the Christian fashion shows why love is the supreme virtue as Christians have always claimed it is: all other virtues pursue some aspect of the human good, i.e., of human existence, but it is love that wills that existence per se, and hence, wills the good per se.

This sort of love is excellently motivated: it illuminates why love is so ethically important on a purely human level, is the sort of love that it makes sense to attribute to the Creator, it satisfies our longing for a fundamental affirmation of our existence that does not merely leave us as we happen to be, and to boot, defuses the problem of evil. It is quite difficult to call a concept in which natural theology, ethics, and fundamental metaphysics neatly conceptually converge 'ad-hoc.'

It's a very odd argument that an abuser can spin a self-serving story using the name of some virtue, therefore that virtue is not a virtue. Virtues are useful to abusers precisely because they are genuine virtues. An abuser can misuse courage, for instance, by appealing to the very true principle that some things are worth fighting for, and it is worth enduring tremendous hardship to achieve (therefore, stick with me). That doesn't mean courage is not a virtue!

One can oppose an abuser only by willing the genuine good of the victim, as founded in a correct understanding of the nature of the human person and a person's intrinsic ends. When one wills the good of the victim, one conforms one's will to the will of the Creator for that victim, since the person's intrinsic ends just are the ends that properly belong to them as the kind of thing they are. By willing these ends, we also oppose privations inflicted upon that victim (since they take away from that victim's existence), but at the same time, we are not so eager to eliminate those privations that we would eliminate the victim themselves (since, after all, it is their positive existence, and not merely the absence of privations, which we seek). Just so with God: because he loves us, he wills the good for us, and because he loves us, he also permits the evils (including Hell) that make up our nature.
